issues.title: Wormhole attacks
issues.author: nicorusti
issues.body:
I feel that the wormhole paragraph is not mature enough for this submission. Some issues: 
* several parts of the content is a duplicate of `5.2.4.  Manipulation of the Path-Selection Process`  in [draft-dekater-scion-controlplane-04
](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-dekater-scion-controlplane/04/)
* some of the mitigations proposed are quite vague
* ~~it does not clearly mention proof of transit as a solution~~

This is the text I removed in #23 , to be reworked for a later submission 
```
## Wormhole attack

### Set up

Scenario: attackers create two core ASes that are geographically far apart. They then announce a link (effectively a shortcut) between these two ASes with
very appealing properties (low latency, few hops, ...).

### Impact
The attacker can now perform blackhole attacks (DoS), greyhole attacks, delay traffic, or similarily impact traffic.

Critically, there is currently no clear way to recover from this situation. In order to recover, ASes that are connected to the
wormhole ASes would need to learn of the problem and stop forwarding the wormhole beacons.

Mitigations:

- Introduce a way for ASes to verify path properties. This would make it harder to install wormholes.
  This could include measuring latency or sense-checking of geolocation information.
- Introduce a way for endpoints to discover path problems.
- Introduce a way for endpoints to report path problems.
- Introduce a way to recover from malicious segments, see {{signalling-faulty-segments}}.
- Adapt the path discovery and dissemination algorithm to allow ASes to have many more than five paths to
  a given remote destination. The attack would then require an (unreasonably) large number of compromised ASes.

A related question is discussed in {{signalling-faulty-segments}}.
```

comments.author: tzaeschke
comments.body:
Apologies, apparently I wasn't quite finished when I committed it. Just in case we decide to add this again, here is a slightly improved version of the text:
```
## Wormhole attack

The wormhole attack is described in {{I-D.scion-cp}}.

### Set up

Scenario: attackers create two core ASes that are geographically far apart. They then announce a link (effectively a shortcut) between these two ASes with
very appealing properties (low latency, few hops, ...).

### Impact

The attacker can now perform blackhole attacks (DoS), greyhole attacks, delay traffic, or similarly impact traffic.

Critically, there is currently no clear way to recover from this situation. In order to recover, ASes that are connected to the
wormhole ASes would need to learn of the problem and stop forwarding the wormhole beacons.

### Mitigations

- Prevention: Introduce a way for ASes to verify path properties. This would make it harder to install wormholes.
  This could include measuring latency (per path or per link) or sense-checking of geolocation information.
- Recovery: Introduce a way to endpoints to detect, report and recover from path problems. This is discussed in {{signalling-faulty-segments}}.
  - Endpoints need (a standardized? way) to detect path problems, such as high latency or packet loss.
  - Endpoints need a way to report path problems to ASes.
  - ASes need a way to report path problems to other ASes (leaf to core, core to core).
  - ASes need a way to recover from reported or detected malicious segments.
```

I'm not sure how proof of transit would help. I think if the two malicious ASes are connected via VPN, it is impossible to proof that the packets had to go through other ASes...?

comments.author: nicorusti
comments.body:
Thank you!

> I'm not sure how proof of transit would help. I think if the two malicious ASes are connected via VPN, it is impossible to proof that the packets had to go through other ASes...? 

If traffic is "swallowed" via a wormhole shortcut, then packets will skip some of the ASes on path. If there is proof of transit, then the proof for the skipped ASes would be missing, revealing the attack. 
On the other hand, it is impossible to prove that packets went though other ASes.. PoT can only prove that traffic did NOT go through the intended ASes. Does it make sense?

issues.title: Path revocation
issues.author: nicorusti
issues.body:
Path revocation is a very complex topic, it was therefore removed from the implementation. It can trigger lots of discussion, and because of that this is also not mentioned in current drafts. I feel the text below needs some more discussion and work before  a submission. 


Text removed in #23 
```
## Signalling faulty segments

Faulty segments are segments that do not work as advertised, i.e. they are either physically faulty
(broken link, high packet loss, jitter, ...) or have faulty metadata suggesting too few hops, too low latency,
too much bandwith, or similar problems.
The fault may be caused by a technical problem (e.g. broken link) or by a malicious adversary.

An example for a malicious adversary is the "wormhole" attack, see {{I-D.scion-cp}} where an AS may be coaxed to
disseminate a faulty segment. How do we recover from faulty segments?
Currently only endpoints may realize that a segment does not work as advertised, either via SCMP errors or simply by traffic degradation.
This would be a possible sequence of events:

* An endpoint realizes that a segment is faulty
* An endpoint needs to signal to its local AS that a segment is faulty
* A Local AS needs to signal to a core AS that a segment is faulty
* A core AS needs to:
  * change policy to exclude faulty segments AND/OR
  * signal other cores and ISDs to stop delivering the segment (they only deliver 5 each, so any faulty segment shoud be avoided)

### Implications

Besides general service degradation, a lack of recovery can worsen the impact of a wormhole attack {{I-D.scion-cp}}.

### Mitigation

* An AS could monitor traffic for SCMP errors, although this only works if these errors are actually generated and forwarded.
* Endpoints need a way to signal faulty segments to ASes. ASes need a way to signal faulty ASes to other ASes (e.g.
core ASes or ASes in other ISDs).
* ASes need adaptive beacon analysis algorithms that allow excluding specific beacons, e.g. beacons that have
  known malicious ASes on path.
* For swift recovery, it would be useful if ASes could communicate the faultiness of faulty segments.
```

comments.body: Is it superexponential with the number of ASes? I thought it was _just_ exponential.

I don't think it would limit the number of available paths, after enough time of beaconing.
Those 5 beacons may be part of a different path than the previous ones. Same for the next ones, and so on.
I think usually the same 5 paths would forwarded every time, if they are the best paths, then should it change and forward other paths? Or not?

Two things: 
- I'd clarify the context for this number.. Is it in total in an overall SCION network? Is it per AS? I think it makes sense to talk about numbers per AS in general
- According to our (@matzf ) calculations and my understanding, if you limit the number of beacons with the "best PCB" practice, then the number is o(N*log(N)). So this would be if you were to not filter the number of beacons at all?
- I'd explain more clearly what "naively" means, e.g. `if there were no limits to the numbers of beacons propagated by each core AS, the number of paths and beacons would grow exponentially`)

```suggestion
* It limits the number of available paths for endpoints such that only 5 path may be available to a given destination. This is especially relevant for
```

In drafts, we use `endpoint`  as per definition in RFC9473. Could you generally use endpoint instead of end host?

> such that only 5 path may be available to a given destination.  

This text gives the impression that there are at most 5 paths between a src and dst, which is not the case. Is this just an edge case? I think in general more paths are available between endpoints

```
  * Unusual path policies, such as geofencing, may not be fulfillable by the limited number of paths on offer.
```
Was this ever an actual problem? Is it an edge case? I've never heard of this before

Are you referring to the `Wormhole Attack` we describe in the CP draft? 
Why is this related to core beaconing scalability?
Wouldn't a wormhole segment work? Is this section about segment revocation?

Not sure it happened yet, simply because we do not have much useful metadata yet (geofencing etc).
I think it can become a problem: if all ASes only forward their best five paths, then these five paths may be disjunct in themselves, but neighboring ASes are probably likely to forward the (almost) same 5 paths. In effect, an endpoint may have more than 5 paths available, but they are likely to be very similar and may not offer the choice that an endpoint desires?
I added an explanation. Does it make sense? Otherwise I can remove the whole bullet point.

For this to happen, these neighbors have to share a common trailing path, e.g., being X our AS:
```
1) a->b->c -> X
2) a'->b'->c' -> X
etc.
```
Paths 1 and 2 would be "similar" if a' ≈ a and b'≈ b, while having c and c' being different neighbors.
Definitely not an impossible situation, but also not common: most likely the trailing path of neighbor c will be different that that of neighbor c', either in AS numbers or interface IDs.

I don't agree with this. It might limit the number of paths if and only if there are no _new_ beacons arriving to the neighboring ASes after **N** beaconing periods. For that to happen, we require that the beaconing step _i+1_ forwards the same beacons than step _i_. OR that the beacons are very short lived and cannot survive longer than one period.
In any other case, period _i+1_ could, and would, forward different beacons to the neighboring ASes.

This is how I would explain it.
- The time needed to propagate all the beacons to the neighboring ASes increments.
- Since all beacons have an expiration time, we have a finite amount of time until a beaconing period will need to forward an already forwarded beacon, just because it expired.
- And, _most importantly_, the semantics of what a "best PCB" means, are defined locally by the **beacon forwarder AS**, not by the receiver AS, who is the actual judge of the quality of the PCB.

I agree with @tzaeschke _iff_ they forward the same PCBs during each beaconing period.
Let me give an example to clarify:
- First AS "A" discriminates good PCBs using latency criteria. This means that for AS "A" only good latency PCBs are forwarded.
- Second AS "B" receives PCBs from AS "A", but "B" discriminates bases on bandwidth. Maybe some PCBs have a good bandwidth, but many were already filtered by "A".
- etc.

If ASes forward _all received beacons_ (in general, and assuming there is no expiration time inside the PCBs), there should not be a problem, since all paths will be eventually discovered.

Now, because reality is that ASes cannot forward all of the PCBs, the non forwarded PCBs (those that an AS never forwards) are the least interesting ones _according to the local criteria of that AS_, which may or may not coincide with that criteria of the next neighbors this PCB will encounter.

I believe this to be clearer if explained in terms of completeness of the graph exploration vs. time needed for it.

See comments above: only if the exploration achieved by this beaconing is very far from a full exploration of the complete graph, when the equality operator here `link1 = link2` means they have the same four tuple `[AS1,interface number1, AS2, interface number2]`

The possibility of attacking the selection of the best paths does not appear due to this beaconing process.
The same issue appears with an e.g. push-pull-publish-subscribe method, as long as the information propagated in the PCBs is trusted by the AS selecting the beacons and paths. Be that information latency, bandwidth, number of hops, etc (anything).

Maybe refresh the process of an endpoint requesting a path from itself as SRC, to a given DST.
This will make clear how the core ASes' control service is contacted, how many times, etc.
This is not immediately clear to me: why _mostly_ redundant information?
Three round trips from the local control service to control services of other two ASes.
I don't understand the approach. Can you clarify?
Although we could revisit the topic, path revocation was studied already, and brought only more problems into the picture. For a full rationale, see the SCION book v2, 5.7 Path Revokation
As a comment: This is essentially what the book promises, that the endpoints will have anyway a big selection to choose paths from.

```suggestion
Critically, there is no current way to recover from this situation. In order to recover, ASes that are connected to the
```
Thanks for the pointer. It turns out, path revocation comes basically for free with 2-phase beaconing :-D.

Is there a concept of emitting information to invalidate a previously authorized PCB?
If so, that is what we call a revocation. If it is not possible to invalidate previously authorized PCB, then I would call it differently, to distinguish from _revocation_ used in the book or previous I-Ds.

Just to clarify the example, we are looking for paths from X to Y:
```
1) Y->a->b->c -> X
2) Y->a'->b'->c' -> X
```
At a first step I'd argue that it is quite likely that, going from Y->X,  we have a'=a. If a=a' then the same argument applies to b=b' and so forth.
Consequently I'd argue that there is a high probability of overlap.

Unfortunately, I don't think there is any analysis or experiments to confirm/reject this. If people think this is wrong then we can remove it. Or I can try to rephrase it as a research question that would need to be clarified whether this may be a problem or not?

Sorry, I don't understand what you are saying. Maybe you can clarify?

My assumption is that an AS will rarely change it's what-is-the-best-PCB algorithm. Consequently, they would always forward the same five segments. They may receive new beacons, but as long as the "best 5" are still among them (and I assume they will be, why shouldn'´t they?), they will continue forwarding these 5 PCBs.
I actually meant from the local endpoint to the local control server. I am less concerned about roundtrips between ASes, they have stonger machines and better connections.
I did. Can you have another look?
Done

Honestly I don't know why they were chosen as 16-48. In the book we also don't say.

>  which is conceivably insufficient 

Wether this is sufficient or not depends on how these would be assigned.. as you say we don't have concrete justifications on these figures, so we also have no justifications wether this is sufficient or not. I'd therefore change language a bit from: 
> using 16 bits for the ISD only offers 65,536 possible assignments which is conceivably insufficient.
Additionally, the justification of these figures is lacking at the moment.

To
> using 16 bits for the ISD only offers 65,536 possible assignments. Further investigation on whether thisis sufficient is needed.
We don't really mandate connectivity in the specification. Is there a reason why you say "require"?

Core AS from ISD1 MUST send PCBs to core AS from ISD2.
That's where the connectivity requirement comes from.
But I don't know if I should change the wording, so that it is clear that both ISDs must be able to communicate via their core ASes, in principle without intermediaries.
We use `ISD-AS` in the drafts, let's keep it consistent
In the case of JPAN, the path storage transparent to any API users.
Nitpick, this is not a bullet point, or is it? :)

Correct. Depending at what layer it stores it (QUIC, UDP transport), it would apply to only that layer and above. E.g. if storing it at the QUIC library level, users of raw UDP packets (maybe videoconferencing tools) would have to use a different technique, as this would not be provided to them; additionally, the QUIC specification for SCION would have to include this step.

The intention is for it to be one point. What I want to convey here is that the path has to be stored somewhere, analogously to storing the sender's address with IP.
Maybe I convoluted the explanation too much.
Should I just simplify it?

In order to send data to the client the server needs to store the path locally (analogous to storing the clients IP/port in a non-SCION scenario).
```

```

1. A newly connected AS first sets its topology offline. Its neighbors have to do the same.
2. The new AS learns about the other border router presence through BFD.
3. The neighbor's border router will consider this interface as active.
4. The neighbor's control plane will use this interface to propagate beacons.
5. The new AS receives new PCBs and can propagate and build paths.
